instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A2141: What is A2141? A2141 is a model number for a 16 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2019 with EMC 3347, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01700..
definitions.820-01700: What is 820-01700? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3217: What is CD3217? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.ISL9240: What is ISL9240? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2018 through 2020.
definitions.PP5V_G3S: What is PP5V_G3S? PP5V_G3S is a 5v power rail present when the system is in a G3S standby state.
definitions.P5VG3S_EN: What is P5VG3S_EN? This signal enables the PP5V_G3S power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.

threads.title: Liquid damaged <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Only powers on with Battery
threads.message:
I have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that had corrosion under <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP>. 
Replaced IC and now device pulls 5v at .3 Amps on charger alone. PPBUS gets 12.3v. 
When connected to battery, it turns on and boots up to desktop just fine but does not charge. Ammeter reads 20v 0. amps with battery connected. 
Replaced <CHIP>ISL9240</CHIP> to no avail. 
Replaced the <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> that was next to the corroded one just incase, but still same results.

threads.title: Liquid damaged <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Only powers on with Battery
threads.message:
If board boots with battery, but doesn't switch to 20V with charger alone, the problem is on USB-C area for sure.
Probably some corroded resistors, or traces.
All 4 ports have exact the same behviour?

Compare diode mode readings around <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> chips between left/right ports.
Inspect <CHIP>U2890</CHIP> and its adjacent resistors.

threads.title: Liquid damaged <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Only powers on with Battery
threads.message:
Sorry for the delayed response. 

All ports have the same issue. 

Diode mode readings between and left and right ports read the same. Also compared with a donor board.

<CHIP>U2890</CHIP> and nearby resistors read normal. Compared using working donor board.

The board has trace damage on Test pad <SIGNAL>UPC_XA_FUALT_L</SIGNAL>, but diode mode reading on this line compared to a donor is the same, so I think this is more of just a test point and not a via or trace.

I am missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4_X_USBC</SIGNAL>.

Just for sheer curiosity, i connected a charged battery and attempted and connected a USB to see if it was detectable in system report.

System report would detect a connected USB in all 4 ports but I would get an error saying that USB needs to be connected to a USB port that has power.
So there is some data going through, but no power on the ports.

threads.title: Liquid damaged <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Only powers on with Battery
threads.message: Check <CHIP>U3500</CHIP> and UB700 voltage at pins 19 & 20.

threads.title: Liquid damaged <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Only powers on with Battery
threads.message:
<CHIP>U3500</CHIP>
Pin 19: 0.02v
Pin 20: 0.02v

UB700
Pin 19: 0.02v
Pin 20: 0.02v

threads.title: Liquid damaged <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Only powers on with Battery
threads.message:
Diode mode to ground readings?

<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> not present there?

threads.title: Liquid damaged <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Only powers on with Battery
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> is missing. I found that to be strange.

Diode reading 0.39 on those points.

threads.title: Liquid damaged <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Only powers on with Battery
threads.message: Run a wire to another point, where <SIGNAL>5V_G3S</SIGNAL> is present...

threads.title: Liquid damaged <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Only powers on with Battery
threads.message: This could be where the issue lies. <SIGNAL>5V_G3S</SIGNAL> is not present anywhere on the board. Is the rail suppose to be always present? It looks like this line is created by <CHIP>U7650</CHIP>. I see there is an enable signal for <SIGNAL>P5VG3S_EN_R</SIGNAL> reading 0v. On my donor board, it looks like it is 3.3v.

threads.title: Liquid damaged <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Only powers on with Battery
threads.message: Is it possible that <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> is the issue? <SIGNAL>P5VG3S_EN</SIGNAL> signal is 0v. I'm curious as to how this computer still powers on to home screen with battery connected.

threads.title: Liquid damaged <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Only powers on with Battery
threads.message: Following the power sequence guide, I have all slpr and awake signals and voltages up until <SIGNAL>PMU_PVDDMAIN_EN</SIGNAL> .

threads.title: Liquid damaged <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Only powers on with Battery
threads.message:
Even CPU power supply controller (<CHIP>U7100</CHIP>) is powered up from <SIGNAL>5V_G3S</SIGNAL>.
Machine can't work without this voltage...

threads.title: Liquid damaged <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Only powers on with Battery
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>5V_G3S</SIGNAL> is only present (5v) when battery connected. 

<SIGNAL>PMU_PVDDMAIN_EN</SIGNAL> comes from <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> but is not present.

<SIGNAL>CHGR_INT_L</SIGNAL> is 1.8v
<SIGNAL>PCH_RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is 3v
<SIGNAL>CHGR_CBC_ON</SIGNAL> under both <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> and <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> so I am unable to test if it is sending a signal to <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> to turn on.

This unit is not detected in DFU mode. How it stands, the USB c ports are not actually getting power with a battery, without a battery, or in DFU mode. I don't believe it is a T2 issue since the ports are not turning on or being detected in DFU mode. I'm leaning toward this being an issue with the TBT controller next to the corroded <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP>. Unless you think there is another point of interest.

threads.title: Liquid damaged <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Only powers on with Battery
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>UPC_XA_FAULT_L</SIGNAL> is an error about USB-C port, sent out by <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>; goes to PCH, via <RESISTOR>R1845</RESISTOR>.
You must have 3V at all these fault signals, <RESISTOR>R1843</RESISTOR>-46.
Incorrect value, will block 5V output power to USB devices.
BTW, only the port with connected device should get 5V.

Of course, I'm talking about the case when board is RUNNING with battery connected.
I was thinking your previous posts reffered to same case too.
Seems that you mix the states, when board runs with battery and also posting something about only charger, when baord is off.

Detecting the problem about no 5V output for USB device (battery connected), may help to diagnose why the ports don't switch to 20V (charger alone).

threads.title: Liquid damaged <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Only powers on with Battery
threads.message:
Interesting. I am glad that you point that out. Fault signal is 0v on all 4 resistors. Comparing with donor board has same diode reading of 0.66.
When connected to battery and running, it is 3.3v and pull 20v, 0amps. 

When testing on donor board, 3.3v is not present on Fault line until device pulls 20v at 0.6 amps

threads.title: Liquid damaged <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Only powers on with Battery
threads.message: Comparing diode reading between donor board and I discovered that <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4_X_USBC</SIGNAL> is reading 0.34 on patient board but 0.5 on donor board.

threads.title: Liquid damaged <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Only powers on with Battery
threads.message: <SIGNAL>UPC_X_5V_EN</SIGNAL> reading 0.61 on this board and 0.53 on donor. I am not sure if that is enough variance for to to be a concern.

threads.title: Liquid damaged <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Only powers on with Battery
threads.message:
5V sould appear at L3500, or LB700 when USB device is connected on the corresponding port.
Voltage may be disabled is a fault signal is detected on that USB port.

Not sure if you've seen Louis video about ISL95870A (GAY) chips.
You should check the one with lower diode mode reading on the coil.
Also check which side of the coil has the lower value.

threads.title: Liquid damaged <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Only powers on with Battery
threads.message:
I was reading in a previous post about that. When you say that 5v appears on those coils when a USB device is connected, would that include a charger, or something else like an USB mouse?

I do recall a video talking about replacing the ISL95870A on new models with an older ISL.

L3500 is reading 0.34 on both sides. 
LB700 0.5

So <CHIP>U3500</CHIP> is of interest. Both sides of L3500 are reading the same in diode. I removed L3500 to get a better reading and I am getting a lower reading on Pin 1 on <CHIP>U3500</CHIP> side.

threads.title: Liquid damaged <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Only powers on with Battery
threads.message:
Then change <CHIP>U3500</CHIP>.
The MLB should send out 5V to USB port only if external device requires it; like pendrive, mouse, not charger.

threads.title: Liquid damaged <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Only powers on with Battery
threads.message: Found a donor board with a replacement ISL95870A and swapped out <CHIP>U3500</CHIP> but looks like nothing has changed. <CHIP>U3500</CHIP> is in close proximity to <CHIP>U8297</CHIP> which is 3.3v TBT switch, which is not generating power. Should <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0SW_TBT_X</SIGNAL> be present to power on USB?

threads.title: Liquid damaged <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Only powers on with Battery
threads.message:
It looks like being used by thunderbolt functions, not for normal USB.
There sholud be something more affected by liquid on the part of pure USB management.

threads.title: Liquid damaged <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Only powers on with Battery
threads.message:
Sorry for taking so long to get back to this one. I was able to determine that when a USB pendrive is connected, the corresponding USB port and <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> it is connected to will generate 5v. However, macOS will report an error saying that USB needs power in order to work. I 

So the USB ports are attempting to turn on but there appears to be a communication issue somewhere on the logic baord.

Looking back at earlier pictures of the board I took before replacing the corroded <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> and <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>, I noticed that the Resistors <RESISTOR>R3100</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R3101</RESISTOR> are connected to <SIGNAL>USB_UPC_PCH_XA</SIGNAL> were significantly corroded. Both resistors were measuring proper resistance of 0 ohms. However, I think this is where my issue maybe.

I am under the suspicion that when liquid killed <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>, the line <SIGNAL>USB_UPC_PCH_XA</SIGNAL> may have been over volted and killed part of the PCH.

Since I have been working off an on with this one for a few months and potentially having a PCH issue, I am deeming it irreparable here. I hope this logic makes sense.

threads.title: Liquid damaged <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Only powers on with Battery
threads.message: <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> must send out 5V to VBUS, when USB device is detected on its port.
